title: Best men's cycling jerseys for autumn
text:
It’s a lot easier to keep cycling through the damp and gloom when you’ve got the right kit – and a decent long-sleeved jersey always tops our list of autumn and winter essentials.

When choosing a jersey look out for features such as water resistance, high collars and lightweight thermal insulation to keep you warm and dry for longer.

More tailored tops are great for speed demons who don’t want fabric flapping around, whereas a relaxed fit will allow you to add a base layer underneath for extra warmth. Here’s our pick of the best long-sleeved jerseys out there this season.

You can trust our independent reviews. We may earn commission from some of the retailers, but we never allow this to influence selections, which are formed from real-world testing and expert advice. This revenue helps to fund journalism across The Independent.

Sportful bodyfit pro thermal: £90, Wiggle

Versions of this jersey are worn by professional racing teams Bora Hansgrohe and Bahrain Merida on winter training rides, so if your physique is less than pro it would be a good idea to size up from your standard fit. We love the two-tone green version we tried but there’s a good range of alternative shades if it’s not your cup of tea. There are some clever details on this one which aren’t immediately obvious – like the extra stretch in the arms and shoulders to aid the fit. A light water resistant finish will stop fine rain getting through and there’s fleece fabric in the back and front panels to keep you warm.

Buy now

Morvelo fire thermoactive: £80, Morvelo

British brand Morvelo has given this excellent top a distinctly Spanish feel to warm up your winter. That blend of red, yellow and orange shades will brighten any ride. It’s not the thickest top in our roundup but it will work well as an extra layer beneath a waterproof, or as a standalone in better weather. You get three pockets, some reflective detailing at the back and a comfortably high neck to beat draughts.

Buy now

Stolen Goat orkaan everyday: £125, Stolen Goat

Stolen Goat reckon this could be the ultimate three-season jersey. It’s got a weatherproof coating that beads of moisture simply run off, and the brand promises the effect won’t diminish with washing. There’s a nicely fleeced backing to the fabric along with that other winter jersey essential – a taller collar. The stand-out feature is the huge reflective panel over the rear pockets – it really stands out in headlights and is much bigger than the reflective strips most jerseys use.

Buy now

Altura firestorm long sleeve jersey: £69.99, Altura

This no-nonsense offering from North Yorkshire proves you don’t have to spend a fortune to get quality winter kit. Despite the bargain price tag it’s not lacking features. There’s a silicone gripper at the waist to stop it riding up, broad bands of reflective dots around the arms and at the tail, plus a fabric strip to prevent the wind getting through the full-length zip. Paired with a decent waterproof, this thick fleece-lined top will see you through anything winter can throw at you.

Buy now

Cafe du Cycliste irma audax: £184, Cafe du Cycliste

Yes, this one’s expensive but it’s a great choice for any style conscious cyclist. We loved the longer arms which will tuck nicely into your gloves on chilly mornings. The merino mix fabric is soft to the touch, warm and breathable. The thicker panel down the front with its chevron pattern doesn’t just look great, it also helps to trap air, giving your torso extra protection from the wind. It’s got a large mesh pocket where you can carry bulkier items such as your gloves or rain jacket. There’s also the usual three cargo pockets plus a zipped security section. An all grey version is available but the black colourway is our favourite.

Buy now

dhb aeron polartec rain defence: £130, Wiggle

Is this a thick jersey or a thin jacket? We can’t make up our minds. The label says jersey but it’s got some very jackety features including a longer tail to keep road spray off your saddle. That’s no bad thing, though. It uses Polartec’s power shield pro fabric to keep the wind out and the drizzle at bay while allowing moisture to escape. Really bright fluo yellow tops like this are a sensible choice even on daytime rides in the darker months. It’s a generous fit, meaning you can wear a base layer beneath it. We liked the addition of a simple storm flap over the two main rear pockets and there’s an extra zipped pocket for your phone.

Buy now

Castelli fondo: £90, Evans Cycles

Here’s a lovely snuggly jersey you’ll be glad of in the colder weather. With a lightly fleeced lining it’s a really good choice on dry but cold days. As usual with Castelli you’ll probably want to size up to make it loose enough to add a base layer. It’s also light enough to pair with a jacket or a gilet for when the conditions are a bit more changeable. We tried the black/fluo version and loved the stripes of yellow on the back and cuffs which help keep you more visible. There’s a substantial neck guard to keep you from rubbing your neck on the zip, and more than enough room in the pockets to fit ride snacks, a phone and even a jacket.

Buy now

Le Col pro aqua zero pinnacle: £135, Le Col

Every item of Le Col clothing we have tried over the years has had a real quality feel about it – and this jersey is no exception. It uses thicker fabric than many of its rivals and has a nice big zip-puller you’ll be able to grip with gloves on. The fleece backing to the material will keep you warm while the hydrophobic coating on the outside will help drizzle to bead and run off before it soaks through. The black and white colourway with its rear reflective stripe really stood out on the road. If you want something less monochrome, take a look at the jaw-dropping orange and blue alternative. The fit is very much on the racy side so you may want to go up a size from your usual.

Buy now

Kalf Club eVent softshell: £100, Evans Cycles

Here’s another jersey with jacket aspirations. It’s got a longer tail plus a storm flap to keep the rain out of those two large rear pockets. Unusually, there’s a third, zipped pocket on the chest for your phone or wallet. The windproof eVent fabric has been treated with a durable water repellent coating to help keep out the damp, and there are stretchy inner cuffs to stop winter winds finding their way up the sleeves. The golden colour is certainly different and should help you to stand out on the road. It’s one to consider if you don’t want to buy both a soft-shell jacket and a long-sleeved jersey this winter.

Buy now

Santini Bordeaux Paris: £79.99, Prendas Ciclismo

Bordeaux Paris was a brutal motor-paced bike race through France that fizzled out in the 1980s, and this classy jersey has a cartoon of a chap riding a “Derny” motorbike on the pocket panel to commemorate it. It’s a top to wear on its own on warmer autumn or spring days, or beneath a jacket in the middle of winter. Lightly-fleeced on the inside, it’s been stitched together by Santini in Italy and that unusual, almost herringbone pattern on the body is made up of a mass of tiny letter Bs and Ps. We reckon it would make a great Christmas present for the cycling history aficionado in your life.

Buy now

The verdict: Men's cycling jerseys

Your choice of winter jersey will be largely dictated by the sort of riding you do. Our best buy from Sportful comes in at under £100 and is a great all-rounder that will work well on its own or beneath a rain jacket. Those who want to blast around the lanes for a couple of hours could do a lot worse than buy the sleek Le Col offering. If you’re commuting or mile-munching take a look at the amazing value Altura which has room underneath for extra layers.

IndyBest product reviews are unbiased, independent advice you can trust. On some occasions, we earn revenue if you click the links and buy the products, but we never allow this to bias our coverage. The reviews are compiled through a mix of expert opinion and real-world testing.
